Graphical Abstract The purpose of this study is to identify the deactivation mechanism(s) that occurs during the aromatization of dilute ethylene at 500 °C on Zn/H-MFI catalyst. More than 15 catalysts, with a Zn/H+ molar ratio ranging from 0 (H-ZSM5) to 1.8 (Zn/H-ZSM5), were prepared by wet impregnation. Deactivation does not result from Zn sublimation, but from coking. The deactivation function and coke deposition can be modelled by simple exponential laws. Moreover, the balance between Lewis (Zn) and Brønsted (H+) acid sites is a good descriptor for predicting the catalyst stability. The coke poisoning has a similar impact on the diminution of micropore volume as well as on the reduction of the number of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The best suited descriptor for describing deactivation is the reduction of the micropore volume. Keywords Zn/H-ZSM-5 Ethylene Deactivation Coke Lewis and Brønsted acid sites 1 Introduction Catalytic Cracking (FCC) is a key process in petroleum refinery. This technology yields light olefins, e.g. ethylene, propylene, butylenes as by-products that are sent to a gas recovery unit. Recovered propylene/butylenes are processed in alkylation or oligomerization facilities to produce additional high-octane gasoline, while unrecovered light olefins (dry gas), including ethylene, are routed to the refinery fuel system. The quantity of light olefins burned in the fuel system can become even more significant as FCC catalysts are employed. The consumption of a potentially high-value product for low-value energy purposes can be avoided by developing technologies to convert ethylene into desirable products such as propylene and aromatics. [1,2] ZSM-5 doped with zinc has proven as suitable catalyst for the aromatization of ethylene at high temperature (500 °C), which mainly yields BTX, light olefins (propylene, butenes) and hydrogen. [3–6]. Zn impregnation on H/ZSM-5 zeolite increases the concentration of Lewis acid sites (LAS) and concomitantly decreases that of Brønsted acid sites (BAS). [4] A high LAS/BAS ratio improves the initial yield of BTX [7]. The main issue for the industrial development of ethylene aromatization is to mitigate catalyst deactivation. [1,2,7] There are many reasons for the deactivation of a bifunctional catalyst such as Zn/HZSM-5 [8], e.g. loss of metal species from the catalyst under reducing conditions [9,10], and/or the coking which may poison or block access to active sites. [11–13]. The deactivation rate also depends on the balance between the two functions. Zhang et al. suggested that the balance between the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites is the key property to obtain both high aromatics yield and high catalyst stability; the suitable LAS/BAS ratio is around of 1 [7]. This study is devoted to the understanding of the impact of the molar ratio of Zn active sites and H+ on the catalyst stability and on the nature and toxicity of coke. More than 15 catalysts, with a Zn/H+ molar ratio ranging from 0 (H-ZSM5) to 1.8 (Zn/H-ZSM5), were prepared by wet impregnation, characterized by different probe molecules (N2, pyridine), and tested in ethylene transformation at 500 °C. The deactivating species and deactivated/regenerated catalysts have also been be characterized. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Material Three series of Zn-containing catalyst were prepared from three commercial zeolites (Zeolyst) with a global Si/Al molar ratio of 15 (CBV 3042E), 40 (CBV 8014) and 75 (CBV 1502). The CBV 3042E and CBV 8014 under ammonium form were calcined under air at 500 °C for 12 h. Zn-containing zeolites were prepared by wet impregnation by stirring protonic zeolite with an aqueous solution of Zn(NO3)2.6H2O at 60 °C for 30 min, in the proportion of 1 g of zeolite per 10 mL of Zn(NO3)2.6H2O solution. The concentration of the precursor salt solution ranges between 0.008 and 0.12 mol L−1 depending of the zinc loading expected. Then, the samples were dried at 120 °C for 12 h without preliminary filtration and calcined at 500 °C under air (60 mL.min-1) for 12 h. 2.2 Catalytic test A typical catalytic test for the ethylene conversion (Air Liquid, > 99 %) was performed at atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed continuous flow quartz reactor at 500 °C with a N2/reactant molar ratio of 19, which correspond to an ethylene partial pressure of 0.005 MPa. The length and diameter of the catalytic bed are 13 and 6 mm, respectively. No pre-bed of inert material was used. In standard condition the weight gas hourly space velocity WHSV (g of injected C2H4 per hour and per g of catalyst) was 2 h−1, and the gas hourly space velocity was 13 300 h−1 which corresponds to a short contact time of 7.5 10-5 h. Before testing, 200 mg of catalyst was compacted, crushed and sieved to obtained homogeneous particles (0.2−0.4 mm). Samples were pre-treated at 500 °C (5 °C min−1) under nitrogen flow (100 mL.min−1) for 1 h. The trace heated lines between reactor and GC are 200 °C. The gaseous products and hydrogen were analysed online by a Varian CP-3800 gas chromatograph equipped with a FID detector using a fused silica J&W GS-Gaspro capillary column (60 m x0.32 mm x4 μm) and a TCD using a J&W PoraPLOT Q-HT capillary column (25 m x0.53 mm x20 μm). GC equipment was calibrated with a gas mixture (C1 to C6 in N2, 800 ppm each compound, Air liquid). The standard deviation of the catalytic data is assessed to 2%. (Fig. SI.1) 2.3 Characterization of the fresh and spent catalysts The elemental composition of the bifunctional catalysts (Si, Al, Zn) was determined before and after ethylene transformation using inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) on an Optima 2000 DV (Perkin-Elmer). The samples (30−40 mg) were mineralized by three successive acid attacks by HNO3 (69 vol. %), HCl (37 vol. %) and HF (40 vol. %) in the proportion 4/2/2 mL, respectively. The mineralization was carried out in sealed vessels at 180 °C under an autogenous pressure of 2.0 MPa for 45 min using a microwave oven (Anton-Parr Multiwave Pro). Finally, 12 mL of a saturated solution of H3BO4 was added to the sample. Textural properties were determined by sorption measurements of nitrogen at −196 °C, using a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 gas adsorption analyzer. Prior to measurement, samples were outgassed at 90 °C for 1 h and 350 °C for 4 h both with a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1. Coked samples were outgassed at 90 °C for 1 h and 150 °C for 1 h to avoid coke desorption. The microporous volumes (Vmicro) were calculated using the t-plot method and the total pore volume was calculated at p/p0 = 0.98. The nature, concentration of acidity were studied by using pyridine as a probe molecule followed by infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) through a Nicolet 5700 apparatus with 2 cm-1 optical resolution. Before analysis, the catalyst was pressed for 2 s at 0.5 ton into a self-supporting wafer (2 cm2) and pretreated from 20 °C to 500 °C under nitrogen flow (100 mL min-1). The fresh and regenerated catalysts were then out-gassed (10-5 bar) for 1 h at 350 °C, after which finally an IR spectrum was taken, while on spent catalyst the pretreatment temperature was 150 °C, with a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1. Then, the sample was cooled to 150 °C and exposed to 1.5 mbar pyridine pressure for 5 min and then outgassed (10-5 bar) for 1 h in order to eliminate the physisorbed pyridine. The FTIR spectrum was taken at 25 °C. The Beer-Lambert-Bouguer law was applied in the form H + o r L = S m A ε , where H + a n d L is the concentration of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites (μmol g-1), A denotes the integrated absorbance of the corresponding IR bands (1545 and 1455 cm-1), which is normalized to zeolite wafer density (ratio of the wafer weight (mg) to wafer surface (cm2), and ε is the integrated molar adsorption coefficient measured at 25 °C: ε1545 = 1.13 and ε1454 = 1.28 cm mol−1. [14] The calibration curves were obtained on a MFI (Si/Al = 27) and a γ Al2O3 by adding to the IR cell a known amount of pyridine vapor from gas admission compartment (0.9122 cm3). All the reported FTIR spectra recorded at 25 °C are normalized to a wafer density (mg cm-2). The coke content and the temperature of coke oxidation (Tox) were obtained with a SDT Q600 TA thermogravimetric analyser under a flow rate of 100 mL min−1 of air up to 900 °C. 2.4 Coke extraction [15] In order to release molecules trapped in zeolite pores, the spent catalyst was dissolved in 51 vol % hydrofluoric acid solution at room temperature during 20 min. HF was neutralized by a boric acid solution and sodium hydrogen carbonate. Coke molecules were extracted by liquid-liquid extraction with CH2Cl2. After total evaporation of the solvent, the solid is dissolved in dichloromethane in order to obtain a concentration into soluble coke of 20 mg L−1. The solution is analysed using a GC–MS (Thermoelectron DSQ). The low temperature of treatment by HF, the short contact time of the acid solution and the coke components as well as the very small contact area between mineral and organic phases allow to avoid any change of coke composition. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the bifunctional catalysts Three series of bifunctional catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation from HZ15, HZ40 and HZ75 commercial zeolites with a Zn loading ranging from 0.3–8.1 wt. %. Zn based catalysts are named by xZny where x is the zinc content and y the Si/Al molar ratio. The TPR study on 2.1Zn40 shows no reduction. Indeed, Biscardi et al. have shown that Zn2+ cations in ion-exchanged 1.07Z14.5 do no reduce even at 877 °C and ZnO crystals begin to reduce to Zn metal and sublime around 480 °C in flowing hydrogen. [16] It should be noted that a pretreatment of 2.1Zn40 under H2 at 500 °C has no impact on activity, selectivity and stability suggesting that the oxidation state of Zn is +2. The textural properties of the commercial zeolites features micropore volumes between 0.15−0.18 cm3 g−1, which is typical value for ZSM-5 zeolite [17]. For the HZ15 and HZ75 catalyst series, the microporous volume is only slightly affected by high Zn loadings, probably due to the deposition of a small amount of subnanometric (ZnO)n particles in the micropores. On the other hand, for the series HZ40, Vmicro decreases with increasing Zn content, which suggests that on this zeolite, which features internal defects, the Zn oxide species (ZnO) may be located in the microcavities formed by the hydroxyl nests. The incorporation of the metal into the framework of HZ40 is confirmed by UV–vis adsorption spectroscopy (Fig. 1 ), which shows an adsorption band at about 265 nm. Zhang et al. to Zn attributed this in the zeolite framework [18]. Incorporation of Zn into the MFI framework can be done by isomorphic substitution by healing silanol nests [19,20]. An adsorption band at about 370 nm-1, which corresponds to the band gap width of macrocrystalline ZnO appears when the Zn loading exceeds 1.4 wt.%. TEM images (Fig. 2 ) clearly show that some (ZnO)n particles cover the external surface of the HZ40 zeolite. On the 3.6Zn40 catalyst, their size (9.1 nm) is twelve times larger than the diameter of the larger void volume within the MFI framework, i.e. 0.70 nm in the channel intersections. It appears that Zn cations, which do not exchange with zeolite protons, precipitates as (ZnO)n species and grow on the outer surface during the solvent evaporation step. Their size therefore depends in part on the exchange capacity of the zeolite. The (ZnO)n particles in 4.1Zn15 and 2.7Zn75 were measured and are of 6.8 and 14.8 nm, respectively. Fig. 3 compares the infrared spectra in the OH stretching region of the three catalyst series. HZ75 has two IR bands: an intense band at 3610 cm−1 (± 2) attributed to the bridged hydroxyl groups (Si-O(H)-Al) and an asymmetric band at 3740 cm−1 ascribed to the terminal silanol groups on the external surface. On HZ40, the shoulder at 3726 cm−1 corresponds to Si−OH located on the intraparticular defects and is correlated with the broad band centred at 3470 cm−1, which is assigned to the hydroxyl nests. The intensities of the bridged OH-band of the three catalysts series decrease partially (Fig. 3b), even with a Zn content in solution two to three times higher than their exchange capacity, which is calculated assuming a Zn/Al molar ratio of 0.5 (1/2), i.e. 0.7, 1.4 and 3.4 wt. % on HZ75, HZ40 and HZ15, respectively. Pyridine adsorbed on zeolites leads to characteristic bands at 1546 and 1454 cm−1 which appear due to protonated pyridine at Brønsted acid sites (BAS) and pyridine coordinated to Lewis acid sites (LAS), respectively. The concentration of pyridinium ions decreases rapidly with Zn addition, then very slightly with further metal incorporation ( Fig. 4 a). The concentration of the Zn-based Lewis acid sites follows the reverse trend as the neutralization of the Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 4b). The ratio between the neutralized BAS and created LAS is two (Fig. 4c). The neutralization of the one protonic site leads to the creation of one Zn Lewis acid site which coordinates two pyridine molecules. The balance between Zn Lewis and Brønsted acid sites (given by the ratio of ZnLewis/H+) is higher than 5 ( Table 1 ). 3.2 Kinetic of deactivation Fig. 5 shows the ethylene conversion at 500 °C under atmospheric pressure against time-on-stream (TOS). HZ15 converts ca 60 % of reactant with almost no deactivation during 280 min. Whereas on HZ40 and HZ75, less than 2% of ethylene is converted, which is apparently in direct contradiction with the results of numerous studies [21–27]. The observed low activity can be ascribed to the severe operating conditions that were employed. Indeed, high temperature [24], low partial pressure of the olefin [24,26,22–27] and short contact times hinder the oligomerization reaction. The activity of HZ15 could be due to the high density of the Brønsted acid sites. The wet impregnation of zinc on zeolite leads to an increase in conversion (except on 0.7Zn15) followed by deactivation, which increases with the zinc loading. 2.1Zn40 catalyst appears to be less active in the transformation of ethylene than HZ15 zeolite. Hence, the initial decline in activity of HZ15 after the addition of Zn is consistent with the neutralization of the very active aluminium pairs. The catalyst deactivation constant (kD, s−1gcata −1) can be assessed from the time-on-stream (TOS) theory by a simple exponential law, which corresponds to a deactivation order of 1: a 280 = a 10 e - k D t with a t and a 10 corresponding to activities on spent and fresh catalysts, respectively. It is worth noting that the TOS theory is based on the assumption that the concentration of active sites is simply a time-dependent power function of the remaining concentration of active sites and that all have the same strength. [28] The deactivation curves fit the exponential law very well (Fig. SI. 2); the catalyst deactivation constant (kD) are shown in Table 1. For each catalyst series; the kinetic deactivation constant depends on the concentration of Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 6 a), on that of Zn-Lewis acid sites (Fig. 6b). The only variable with which a correlation with kd can be observed for all the catalyst series is the Lewis/Brønsted ratio (Fig. 6c). Indeed, the dependence of kD with LAS or BAS follow different trends for each Si/Al ratio. This correlation indicates that deactivation occurs via a bifunctional mechanism. The loss of activity between 10 and 280 min (a280/a10) increases unexpectedly with decreasing BAS concentration. For each catalyst series, the higher the concentration of Brønsted acid sites the higher the catalyst stability. In addition, at iso-concentration of the acid sites, the lower the Si/Al zeolite ratio the lower the residual activity. (Fig. 7 a). In contrast, a280/a10 decreases with increasing of the concentration of Zn-Lewis acid sites (Fig. 7b) and at iso-concentration of ZnLewis the lower the Si/Al zeolite ratio the lower the residual activity. Yet, the loss of activity, regardless of the Si/Al ratio, follows an exponential law of the ZnLewis/H+ ratio (Fig. 7c): ϕ = a 280 a 10 = 0.953 e - 0.53 Z n L e w i s H + . Hence, the balance between Lewis and Brønsted acid sites is a good descriptor for predicting catalyst stability. 3.3 Kinetic of coking Deactivation does not result from a loss of Zn by sublimation since the metal content after 280 min of reaction is identical to that of the fresh catalyst (Fig SI.3). Deactivation is only due to coking. Table 1 reports the coke content (wt. % C) on the catalysts after 280 min of reaction. The carbon content, which is low on protonic catalysts, (1.4 wt. % on HZ15) reaches up to 7.5 wt. % on bifunctional catalysts. The deactivating effect of coke on the kinetics was studied on the 3.4Zn15 catalyst. The coke formation on the bifunctional catalyst is slow and follows a linear regression (∼0.01 gcoke gcata −1 h−1) with an intersection point at 1.7 wt. % (Fig. 8 a). This value is close to the coke content obtained on protonic zeolite. The loss of catalytic activity Φ = a 280 a 10 fits with an exponential dependence on the coke content (Cc): Φ = C Z e - α k C C (Fig. 8b). This deactivation function is frequently used to describe the loss of activity [12,29–31]. The constant in the exponential, αk in (wt. %-1), is the so-called coking constant. αk is equal to 0.307 wt. %-1, which is ca 6 times lower than the coke formation in the catalytic cracking of 2,2,4 trimethylpentane on a USY zeolite at 480 °C, but αk is in the same range as that of hydride transfer (0.653), protonation and PCP isomerization (0.148), β scission (t-t) (0.407) and protolytic scission (0.445). [32] The higher value of deactivation constant (αk) for coke formation in FAU zeolite is certainly due to the presence of supercages. The deactivation function has a pre-exponential factor (A), which means that one part of coke is trapped on the zeolite without significant impact on catalyst activity. On the HZ15 zeolite, the low coke content (1.4 wt. %) has almost no impact on the catalyst stability. Some of coke molecules could simply be trapped by silanol groups without impact on catalyst activity [33] and Brønsted acidity (Table 1). Subtracting of the total coke with that measured on the protonic zeolite, gives a pre-exponential factor of 1 (Fig. 8b) and in the case of the coking rate a straight line through the origin (Fig. 8a). Hence, there are two types of coke: a spectator coke (minority) and deactivating coke (majority). The deactivation function (φ) can be modelled by an exponential law of the coke content or the balance between the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. This indicates that these two parameters are related, which suggests that deactivation occurs by poisoning of the Lewis and Brønsted dual sites. Fig. 9 shows the infrared spectra in the OH stretching region of the 3.4Zn15 catalyst after different reaction time. After 30 min of reaction, the intensity of the silanol band decreases significantly then remains constant, indicating their role as a coke trap. [33] The intensity of Si-O(H)-Al decreases continuously with increasing coke content, while that of the hydroxylated extraframework species seems much less sensible to coke deposits. Fig. 10 displays for the 3.4Zn15 catalyst, the losses of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites and micropore volumes as a function of time and coke content. The loss kinetics of Brønsted acid sites is proportional to reaction time (Fig. 10a) and coke content (Fig. 10b) when coke trapped on silanol groups is subtracted (Fig.SI.4). The loss kinetics of micropore volumes follows the same trend, while the loss kinetics of Lewis acid sites begins after a slightly higher coke content (4−1.4 = 2.6 wt. %). The increase of LAS concentration suggests that some coke precursors present a Lewis acid site character. Indeed, Cerqueira et al. observed that the coke deposit on USHY zeolite leads to a decrease of the concentration of protonic sites, while that of Lewis sites increases after coking. [34] 3.4 Deactivation and selectivity Fig. 11 compares, as a function of ethylene conversion, the molar yields of H2, CH4, ethane, propylene, butenes, and aromatics obtained after 10 and 280 min. On fresh HZ15 zeolite, oligomerization-cracking reaction occurs, yielding propylene and butane. Aromatics result from the transformation of naphthenes by dehydrogenation and hydride transfer reactions, producing hydrogen and paraffins (mainly ethane), respectively. CH4 results more from the dealkylation reaction of toluene and xylene than from α-scission of olefins. (The operating conditions favour the dealkylation reaction rather than the alkylation reaction). Despite high yields of coking molecules such as light olefins as well as a high temperature and high density of acidic sites, the formation of coke remains low (1.4 % wt. %) even after a long period of operation. Catalyst deactivation is slow. The operating conditions of ethylene aromatization such as a low contact time and mainly a low partial pressure of ethylene (PC2H4 = 5.2 10−3 MPa, do not promote the coke formation by the conventional acid mechanism. The wet impregnation of Zn completely changes the selectivity of the acid catalyst. C4H8 is clearly a primary product, while CH4, C3H6, H2 and aromatics composed of benzene (B), toluene (T) and also xylene (X) and ethylbenzene (EB), are secondary products. These products could practically be considered as primary products (Fig. 11) because they are produced simultaneously from a very low conversion, ca 2% (extrapolated value). Hydrogen resulting from the dehydrogenation of naphthenes or olefinic naphthenes, is also consumed at high conversion through the hydrogenation of olefins (mainly ethylene) into light alkanes. The hydrogenation of ethylene has a direct impact on the yield of aromatics, limiting or even decreasing it when a large part of ethylene is hydrogenated. In the absence of hydrogenation side-reactions (X < 30 %), the coke content is proportional to the initial aromatics yield (XAr), but when H2 begins to be consumed for ethane formation, the coke content decreases more on the series 40 than the series 15, resulting in lower XAr. (Fig. 12 ). The lower coke content could be attributed to the hydrogenation of coke precursors [21,22], since hydrogenation reactions take place at high conversion. The proportionality suggests that the coke maker molecules on bifunctional catalysts are aromatics. The catalyst deactivation has no impact on the selectivity as shown in Fig. 11. It should be noted that the selectivity into hydrogenated products is slightly higher on spent catalysts despite a lower hydrogen yield, indicating that coke deposition has a greater impact on the dimerization sites than on the hydrogenation sites. 3.5 Characterization of the deactivating species The bands of carbonaceous compounds deposited on catalysts are observed on two IR spectra domains: i) 2700−3100 cm−1 (Fig. 13 ): CH stretching modes of aromatic and paraffinic groups, ii) 1300−1700 cm−1 (Fig. 14 ): CC stretching modes of unsaturated (olefin, polyenyl, aromatic and polyaromatic) groups and CH bending of paraffinic groups. The band at 2935 cm−1 is assigned to the asymmetric stretching mode of CH2 groups, and 2957 and 2864 cm−1 correspond to the symmetric stretching mode of CH2 and CH3. The intensities of the bands of coke increase with the Zn loading on all series, but when hydrogenation side-reactions occur especially on series 15 and 40, their intensities decrease significantly, which indicates a lower degree of alkyl groups on the aromatic rings. The attribution of bands in region between 1300−1800 cm−1 is more complex, as in this region appear different stretching modes of CC condensed and non-condensed aromatics; and also bending vibrations of CH. Regardless of the coke content, all spent catalysts exhibit bands at 1591, 1470, 1426 and 1371 cm−1, which can be attributed to coke molecules with a number of aromatic rings higher than 3. [35] It should be mentioned that the IR spectra are recorded on catalysts which have been operated for 280 min; this long time allows the growth of coke precursors into polyaromatic compounds. The intensities of the bands of coke in this region are proportional to the coke content (Figure SI. 5) which reaches a plateau at ca 6 wt.%, probably due to signal saturation. The composition of coke trapped inside the zeolite pore is determined on 2.1Zn40 and 5.6Zn40 by mineralizing the zeolite matrix and subsequently analyzing the organic leftovers by liquid-liquid extraction with CH2Cl2. GC/MS analysis (Figure SI. 6) shows that the coke composition on both catalysts consists of polyaromatic compounds such as naphthalene, anthracene, phenanthrene, pyrene and benzo[e]pyrene, which are alkylated by only two or three methyl groups, When the hydrogenation side reaction occurs on the 5.6Zn40 catalyst the number of methyl groups is limited to one. The degree of alkylation of coke molecules is relatively low compared to that observed on coke molecules formed during the transformation of alcohols at 350 °C, with more than 10–12 alkyl groups. [33,35] The low coke content on the catalysts, despite a high reaction time, could be due to a low degree of alkylation of the coke molecules. Indeed, the mechanism of coke formation occurs by alkyl side chain growth [15]. 3.6 Characterization of the spent catalysts The residual micropore volume and the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites remaining after 280 min of reaction are reported for the three catalyst series in Table 1. The volume apparently occupied by coke (Va), deduced from the physisorption measurement, is roughly proportional to its content (Fig. 15 a). The volume really occupied by the coke molecules (VR) can be assessed by assuming that the density of coke is close to that of phenanthrene, anthracene pyrene and benzo[e]pyrene: 1.18, 1.25, 1.27 and 1.24 g cm−3 respectively. Therefore, the coke density in this study is chosen to be 1.25 g cm-3. A VR/VA value of 0.56, (Fig. 15b) indicates a blockage of access of the adsorbate molecules to a part of the microporosity unoccupied by the coke molecules. Indeed, the coke molecule trapped at the channel intersections of the MFI zeolite completely blocks their access, without occupying the totality of their volume. The loss of micropore volume results in a progressive deactivation of the bifunctional catalyst ( Fig. 15c), indicating that the deactivation occurs by poisoning and not by pores blocking as with mordenite zeolites. [36] Fig. 16 shows the proportion of the Brønsted and Lewis sites neutralized by coke: 1 - H + 280 H + 0 (Fig. 16a) and 1 - P y L 280 P y L 0 (Fig. 16b), respectively. The proportion of protonic sites neutralized rises rapidly with the deposition of coke, but after only 2 wt. %, it remains constant and partial (70 %) despite the increase of the coke content and substantial pore blocking (VR/VA = 0.56). This apparent disagreement between quantification of residual acid site and microporous volume analysis, can be easily explained by considering that the coke molecules which are trapped at the channels intersections of MFI zeolite completely block their access, without occupying the totality of the volume. [37] The proportion of Lewis acid sites neutralized by coke is less evident (Fig. 16b), due to the proportion of coke poisoning the Brønsted acid sites and the presence of Zn-Lewis acid sites. On the protonic zeolites, the number of Al-Lewis acid probed by pyridine is higher after coke deposits (Table 1), which means that some coke molecules are able to coordinate pyridine. Nevertheless, it appears as main trend that the proportion of neutralized Zn-Lewis acid sites increases with increasing coke content, causing catalyst deactivation (Fig. 15d). The deactivation results in the neutralization of the Zn-Lewis acid sites, which are located in the zeolite micropores. 3.7 Catalyst regeneration The coke combustion occurs between 400 °C and 700 °C. Fig. 17 shows the temperatures at which 50 (T50) and 90 % (T90) of coke is burnt as a function of the concentration of Brønsted ( Fig. 17b) and Lewis Zn ( Fig. 17a) acid sites, the ZnLewis/H+ molar ratio ( Fig. 17c), the micropore volume of the spent catalyst ( Fig. 17d) and coke content ( Fig. 17e). T90 is almost identical on all spent catalysts (i.e. 630−650 °C), in contrast to T50, which is between 465−585 °C. The coke combustion depends mainly on the accessibility of oxygen to the coke rather on the redox and acidic properties of the bifunctional catalyst. Zn metal does not participate to the coke combustion. The accessibility and coke content are strongly related. The regeneration was studied on 3.6Zn40 catalyst through two reaction-regeneration cycles (Fig. 18 ). The regeneration was carried out under mild conditions, i.e. at the same temperature as the ethylene transformation temperature (500 °C) for 12 h. Despite the low temperature used, all coke molecules were removed. But only a portion of the acidic properties are recovered after regeneration. The concentration of LAS is lower than on the fresh catalyst in favour of a slight increase of BAS (Table 2 ). This impacts the performance of the catalyst as the catalytic activity is reduced. In addition, a second regeneration step leads to a radical change in acidic properties, mainly for Lewis acid site and slight loss of Zn content. Despite mild regeneration conditions; deactivation is partially irreversible, due to modification of acidity during coke combustion. In order to verify this assumption a milder regeneration process should be used, such as non-thermal plasma. [38,39] 4 Conclusion The selective transformation of light olefins into aromatics, which are more valuable and versatile feedstocks for the chemical industry, is one of the major challenges in petrochemistry. ZSM-5 doped with zinc is a proven catalyst for the aromatization of ethylene at high temperature (500 °C). Yet, the coking is the greatest drawback of this reaction, as all the conditions are present to promote its formation: confined acid sites, presence of aromatics and light olefins (coke precursors) and high temperature. However, Brønsted acid sites, even with an acidity exalted by the presence of extraframework species, yield relatively low coke formation. The coking is favoured by the presence of Zn-Lewis acid sites. However, its rate remains rather limited due to the low degree of alkyl groups on the aromatic rings, which impedes the growth of coke. Therefore, reducing diffusion path length by zeolite hierarchization seems very promising to mitigate coke formation. The catalyst stability depends on the balance between the Zn-Lewis and Brønsted acid sites and the yield into desired products: hydrogen and aromatics on the content of Zn species, but when its concentration is high hydrogen is consumed. Hence, the best compromise for an active and stable catalyst in ethylene aromatization consists to have a moderate balance between Zn-Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, around 1.5 and 2. In addition, the development of this process requires a fine management of the regeneration stage. CRediT authorship contribution statement Aurélien Bonnin: Investigation, Writing - original draft. coredata.dc:description: The purpose of this study is to identify the deactivation mechanism(s) that occurs during the aromatization of dilute ethylene at 500 °C on Zn/H-MFI catalyst. More than 15 catalysts, with a Zn/H+ molar ratio ranging from 0 (H-ZSM5) to 1.8 (Zn/H-ZSM5), were prepared by wet impregnation. Deactivation does not result from Zn sublimation, but from coking. The deactivation function and coke deposition can be modelled by simple exponential laws. Moreover, the balance between Lewis (Zn) and Brønsted (H+) acid sites is a good descriptor for predicting the catalyst stability. The coke poisoning has a similar impact on the diminution of micropore volume as well as on the reduction of the number of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The best suited descriptor for describing deactivation is the reduction of the micropore volume.
coredata.dc:title: Deactivation mechanism and regeneration study of Zn/HZSM-5 catalyst in ethylene transformation
